verses.text: Jude, a servant of Jesus Christ and brother of James, to those who are called, beloved in God the Father and kept for Jesus Christ:
verses.comment: Jude identifies himself with humility and connects his authority to the family of James, showing the importance of apostolic succession. He acknowledges God's active role in calling and preserving believers.

verses.text: May mercy, peace, and love be multiplied to you.
verses.comment: The triple blessing reflects a fullness not only of grace but also of communal unity and love, a recurring theme in the apostolic writings.

verses.text: Beloved, although I was very eager to write to you about our common salvation, I felt compelled to write and urge you to contend earnestly for the faith which was once for all delivered to the saints.
verses.comment: This verse emphasizes the unchanging and apostolic nature of the faith, handed down once for all—a reference to tradition and doctrinal stability, echoing the importance of maintaining unity through teachings received from the apostles.

verses.text: For certain people have slipped in unnoticed, who long ago were marked out for condemnation, ungodly ones who twist the grace of our God into a license for immorality and deny our only Master and Lord, Jesus Christ.
verses.comment: Jude warns of false teachers and immorality, echoing the need for sound doctrine and moral discipline within the community. Calling Jesus 'Master and Lord' underlines His divinity and authority over the church.

verses.text: Now I want to remind you, though you once knew it, that the Lord saved a people out of the land of Egypt, but afterward destroyed those who did not believe.
verses.comment: This verse recalls divine judgment on unbelief, emphasizing the need for perseverance in faith. The Lord’s actions reveal both mercy and justice—a spiritual principle carrying through both Testaments.

verses.text: And the angels who did not keep their own position but abandoned their proper dwelling, He has kept in eternal chains under darkness for judgment on the great day.
verses.comment: Angelic rebellion parallels human rebellion, illustrating the seriousness of abandoning God-given roles and the consequences of spiritual pride.

verses.text: Just as Sodom and Gomorrah and the surrounding cities, which, in sexual immorality and unnatural desire, serve as an example by suffering the punishment of eternal fire.
verses.comment: The historic judgment on Sodom and Gomorrah underscores divine justice and the reality of eternal consequences—a warning against both doctrinal and moral errors.

verses.text: Yet in the same way these people also, relying on their dreams, defile the flesh, reject authority, and blaspheme glorious beings.
verses.comment: Rejecting authority and blaspheming spiritual realities reflects a deeper rejection of the sacred order established by God and passed through apostolic leaders.

verses.text: But when the archangel Michael, disputing with the devil about the body of Moses, did not dare to pronounce a blasphemous judgment, but said, 'The Lord rebuke you.'
verses.comment: Michael’s humility and respect for divine authority model how spiritual leaders should exercise discernment and respect, hinting at the role of mediators in intercession and spiritual warfare.

verses.text: But these people blaspheme what they do not understand and are destroyed by all that they, like unreasoning animals, understand instinctively.
verses.comment: A warning against relying on mere instinct or personal interpretation rather than apostolic teaching and spiritual discernment.

verses.text: Woe to them! For they have gone the way of Cain, rushed headlong into Balaam’s error for profit, and perished in Korah’s rebellion.
verses.comment: Highlights three Old Testament stories showing consequences of envy, greed, and rebellion against spiritual leadership—a call to faithful obedience to authority.

verses.text: These are hidden reefs at your love feasts, feasting with you without fear, shepherds who care only for themselves; clouds without water, carried by the winds; autumn trees without fruit, twice dead, uprooted;
verses.comment: The vivid metaphors show the spiritual danger of those who corrupt the community. Reference to 'love feasts' points to the sacramental unity of the early church.

verses.text: Wild waves of the sea, casting up the foam of their own shame; wandering stars, for whom the gloom of deep darkness has been reserved forever.
verses.comment: Imagery here portrays restlessness of those outside the true faith, and the severe consequences of separation from divine light.

verses.text: It was also about these that Enoch, the seventh from Adam, prophesied, saying, 'Behold, the Lord comes with tens of thousands of His holy ones,'
verses.comment: Citing ancient prophecy emphasizes the unity between Old and New Testament revelation, highlighting the continuity of divine judgment and the role of saints in God’s victory.

verses.text: to execute judgment on all and to convict all the ungodly for all their works of ungodliness which they have committed and for all the harsh things that ungodly sinners have spoken against Him.
verses.comment: Describes the final judgment, reinforcing personal accountability before God. Stresses importance of pure doctrine and moral life.

verses.text: These are grumblers, fault-finders, following their own passions; their mouths speak boastful words, flattering people for their own advantage.
verses.comment: Warns against self-serving behavior and divisiveness, which endanger the unity and holiness of the church.

verses.text: But you, beloved, remember the words spoken beforehand by the apostles of our Lord Jesus Christ.
verses.comment: Calls the believers to submit to apostolic teaching and tradition, emphasizing the importance of remembering and obeying the words handed down from the apostles.

verses.text: They said to you, 'In the last time there will be scoffers, following their own ungodly desires.'
verses.comment: Apostolic prophecy of the end times, noting continual need for vigilance and the staying power of the apostolic faith in confronting error.

verses.text: These are the ones who cause divisions, worldly people, devoid of the Spirit.
verses.comment: Describes those outside the fullness of spiritual life who produce division; highlights unity as a sign of authentic spiritual authority.

verses.text: But you, beloved, building yourselves up in your most holy faith and praying in the Holy Spirit,
verses.comment: Encourages spiritual growth through prayer and communal faith, highlighting the importance of unity in the Spirit and ongoing sanctification.

verses.text: keep yourselves in the love of God, waiting for the mercy of our Lord Jesus Christ that leads to eternal life.
verses.comment: This verse has both individual and communal aspects, invoking perseverance in grace and constant hope for final salvation.

verses.text: And have mercy on those who doubt;
verses.comment: Advises gentle restoration of those struggling with faith, showing the church as a place of mercy and healing.

verses.text: save others by snatching them out of the fire; to others show mercy with fear, hating even the garment stained by the flesh.
verses.comment: Highlights the urgency of evangelism and the careful approach needed to maintain personal holiness, balancing mercy with discernment.

verses.text: Now to Him who is able to keep you from stumbling and to present you blameless before the presence of His glory with great joy,
verses.comment: This doxology emphasizes God's power to preserve believers and present them holy, referencing the role of perseverance through grace.

verses.text: to the only God, our Savior, through Jesus Christ our Lord, be glory, majesty, power, and authority, before all time and now and forever. Amen.
verses.comment: The conclusion exalts God’s eternal dominion through Jesus, echoing the worship and recognition of God's sovereignty in the life of the church. The high Christology (identifying Jesus as Lord and Savior) mirrors ancient hymns and points to the centrality of liturgical prayer.
